Once upon a time, there was a group of French people who had always lived only in Paris. They had seen nothing else. One day, they had the idea to formalize what a human could be. So they looked at the humans directly at their fingertips, and listed different properties to try to characterize them. Since they had living examples of humans satisfying all these properties, it was clear that their properties characterized the humans of Paris. Which meant, in their minds, humans at all (having seen nothing else). One of these properties was "A human necessarily likes cheese". All humans in Paris satisfied it. But a far-sighted scientist thought that this property did not necessarily seem to be attached to the intrinsic notion of human itself, and that the choice of this property to characterize a human seemed arbitrary. So he tried a new list of properties by removing this property ("like cheese"). He unrolled the implications, and found with surprise that nothing in his calculations opposed the existence of such "objects" (humans not liking cheese). However, the shocked Parisians claimed loud and clear that it was "absurd", that one had never seen "someone who didn't like cheese", and "that these people couldn't exist". It was also heard that "they couldn't really be human". The idea was proposed to burn the scientist at the stake. To save his life, he had to flee his hometown and settle elsewhere.
Time passed, and our scientist finally met humans in distant lands who did not like cheese. So he had found an example of existing objects, satisfying the properties he had posed. He returned to his city and presented them to the Parisians. The skepticism was palpable. They looked at them very fixedly. Then, after several days of observation, they finally had to face the facts: there were real humans who did not like cheese. Although this property seemed intuitive and natural to them, the facts seemed to show that their intuition (probably conditioned by their environment) was wrong. It now seemed very unreasonable to redefine the notion of human, to exclude those who did not like cheese. Because in them, everything worked almost like the humans they were used to. Time passed, and it was finally accepted that these individuals were indeed humans. They settled down and eventually settled in Paris. With even more time, it turned out that these humans even made an important civic contribution (through their work, knowledge and skills, ...) to this new, and richer, beautiful city of Paris. 🙃

My ex prof tried to trick us - he disguised Fermats problem as a problem in Q. Any two rational numbers raised to a power greater than 2 have the sum of 1. My response on the paper was "its impossible", when I got the paper back he had put "Why?"
It's called elliptical curves nowadays

Any equation with power greater than 2  will produce a graph that lies between the circle and the square. Asymptotically, as you increase the power to infinite, the  line becomes more "squarish". So now you do the integration to get the area under several regions, it seemed to boil down to a proof  of whether the difference between an irrational number and a rational number was irrational.
For Fermat, draw the unit square on your graph with x,y = 1,1, inscribe the circle with radius 1, then in the positive quadrant you can see exactly what I mean.
I suspect Fermat had the same idea - put it on a graph
I might post a 10 slide graphic of what Wiles said in hundreds of pages

The Riemann-Zeta Function, which states ζ(s)=1/1^s + 2/2^s + n/n^s must be complex. For even negative numbers, s= -2k, meaning k is real. Then, 1/1^-2k+ 2/2^-2k+..., which implies k is a complex number; k=a+bi. But this is a clear contradiction! Therefore, the Riemann Hypothesis cannot exist!

16:45 “The Zeta function, by definition...” within a two-dimensional representation of the analytical space used. Extend that analytical space, and you have more possibilities.

That claim is the same as saying that there’s only one way, by definition, to represent the square root of a real number...on a single number line. The moment you extend a number line into a complex plane, your definition also becomes extended.

This leads you to examining what a complex-complex power does. A power that has three dimensions instead of just a “real part/i-hat” and an “imaginary part/j-hat.” If you add another “imaginary-imaginary part/k-hat” to a power, then you necessarily have to describe the output in three dimensions instead of just 1 for real numbers or 2 for complex numbers.

15:30 Instead of “extending” the grid lines to the right of x=1, consider why that boundary exists. It is the consequence of the multiplicative identity being 1. With that in mind, consider 1 as being a boundary that can be represented in the same way that i is a boundary in a complex plane resulting in limiting the result of a complex power to a unit circle.

Treat x=1 like i, and wrap it around the origin. This will allow you to see how the “left” and “right” of the graph are related by translating “left” and “right” to “inner” and “outer.” Once you have done that, you can “flip” it “down” and add a third dimension that represents the amount of “space” “inside” the barrier of 1 as a curved space outside the other two dimensions.

From a physics standpoint, you’ve basically described the transition from flat space to curved space as described by Einstein’s general theory of relativity. You can also view it as the transition from from real space to singularity space inside the event horizon of a black hole, where 1 represents the event horizon.

From this perspective, the Riemann challenge becomes an exercise in describing the singularity (represented by 0 in this challenge) which is the intersection between General Relativity and Quantum Theory: The Grand Unified Theory.

5:40 You’ve basically described the basics behind string theory in which you wrap the “imaginary dimension on itself and have it exist separately from our conventional spatial dimensions. The micro spatial dimensions don’t “exist” to our physical realms, but they help explain the forces which affect our material reality by existing just outside of those three physical dimensions in their own micro dimensions.

I believe the problem with some mathematical conventions are the similarities between terms.

i is used to denote “imaginary” or root(-1). All it really means is that we are defining the existence of a value outside of a single dimension in which it does not exist. When we process a vector (one dimension) with another vector (one dimension) that is defined with parameters that do not exist for the first vector, we add another dimension to our understanding of each vector to create a space in which we can parameterize both vectors. This higher dimensional understanding comes with newer processes that are similar to processes in a single dimension. This process leads to naming each new dimension with basis vectors called i-hat, j-hat, k-hat, etc.

The use of i to denote a new dimension outside of the real number dimension is the same thing as using j-hat to extend understanding from i-hat. It is clunky to use i in one context to denote a SECOND dimension while using i-hat to denote the FIRST dimension in another context. On top of all that, we also use x, y, and z to denote one, two, and three dimensional physical spaces as well as analytical spaces that are visually represented by graphs.

A way someone explained to me how cool complex analysis could be, before I took the course, was about how restrictive some simple definitions can be.
For a real function f(x) to be continuous at x=c, you just need to look at the interval (f(c)-δ,f(c)+δ). But for a complex function, there's the whole circle/disc of values within a radius δ from f(c). And you need to find an ε so that the whole disc radius ε from c maps to within the radius δ disc. So if f:ℂ→ℂ meets that definition of continuous, then there's all sorts of things we can say about it.

Right around 9:00, I think what we're really seeing is 4 dimensional curvature, just relegated to the pair of distinct 2d graphs (one for the input, another for the output) because we aren't able to directly perceive 4 dimensions. The real number graphs (certainly Cartesian coordinate planes, at least for the type of math you do in high school) that deal solely in real numbers are 2 dimensional because you have 1 dimension of input (for example, in the Cartesian system, X) and 1 dimension of output (Y). We can easily see 2 dimensions at once in our 3d world, so we can draw out a function like Y = X^2 and visually observe its essential 2d behaviors - for example, the way it curves upward.

Just as the 2d function Y = X^2 has a different derivative at each point, so that at smaller values of X it curves more slowly, and at larger values, more rapidly, we're observing here the differing rates of change in the 4d curvature of the 4d complex function based on differing inputs. Because you'd need 4 dimensions to represent these graphs fully - both the input and output have 2 dimensions each (the real and imaginary components of a complex number). All we can do is show them side by side. The 2d analogue of this would be to represent the function Y = X^2 with two lines; one line for the input values, and one line for the output values.

With these two lines you would observe that, for smaller inputs, the output doesn't move away as quickly (e.g. at X = 1, Y = 1, so it didn't move at all) but for larger values of X, you'd see the value on the output line moves away much more rapidly (e.g. if you have X = 2 on the input line, for the output line you would be at 4, which moved away more rapidly). So we're observing two distinct sets of one-dimensional movements - the first, the movement along the input line, testing different input values; and the second, the movement on the output line, to see how the outputs behave relative to the inputs.

In the same way, for the 4d complex function, 3blue1brown's diagram here shows two distinct sets of two dimensional movements, because we have to break single 4d function into two 2d graphs, one for the inputs, and one for the outputs, just as I cited the example of breaking a 2d graph into one 1d line for input, and one 1d line for output. So this 2d "spiralling" movement as he goes from the 2d input plane to the 2d output plane is analogous to the 1d "stretching" we'd see as we went from the 1d input line to the 2d output line, for Y = X^2 in this example.

I suspect that just as, for the 2d function Y = X^2, we'd see more "stretching" as X gets bigger (like I said before, at X = 1, there's no stretching at all, because the value on the output line is Y =1, because 1^2 = 1; then at 2 on the input line, we stretch to 4 on the output line, then at 3 on the input line we stretch to 9 on the output line, and so forth - increasingly rapid "stretching"), the increasingly rapid spiralling as we go from certain parts of the 2d input plane to the 2d output plane corresponds to the 4d curvature that's actually going on. This is the same way Y = X^2 exhibits a 2d curvature, that you can easily see, the way it curves upward precipitously at an increasing rate for increasing values of X.

I might be wrong on this next part, but I would guess we can observe the effect more easily by focusing on one distinct point at a time in the 2d input plane, and seeing how it translates to the 2d output plane (well obviously that much is correct; it's his own recommendation). So (and here's where I might be wrong but I think I'm right) we see when inputting the imaginary value i into the function f(s) = s^2, we get a 90 degree curvature over to the output, which is -1. Then, when s = -1, putting it into the same function instead gives us a 180 degree curvature, over to +1. I believe this is just like how going from 1 to 2, in the 2d example, we see greater stretching from the input line to the output line with bigger input values. Whereas before it was a difference in 1 dimensional "stretch", here it's a different in 2d rotation. The 1 dimensional stretch was used in the representation of a 2d function; this 2d rotation is used in the representation of a 4d function.

The reason I felt I might be wrong is because surely you don't just spiral along this one unit circle, because that might suggest that you get the same degree of movement dependent only on one dimension of input (the imaginary dimension in this case?) so that even with inputs that have different real components, it's the same rotational movement from one input to another. Clearly, of course, the "real" component (or whatever it is I'm missing) also influences the transformation from the 2d input plane to the 2d output plane. Perhaps I'm correct in supposing that one of the dimensions of the transformation from the input to the output planes is rotation, and maybe the other is a "stretching" component predicated on the real components of the inputs, as in how an input with a certain real component maps over to the output plane compared to another input with a differing real component?

That last paragraph was convoluted, I don't quite understand my own confusion and I've already typed too much. But I just think it's really fascinating how what we're really describing here is a 4d function. I have no doubt mathematicians have extensively tried to describe the 4d nature of this function, e.g. its qualities such as curvature and so forth, and whatever else (if anything else) may exist in 4d that isn't simply an embellishment of principles that already exist in 3d. But it sure would be way easier to study these if we could only perceive 4d somehow.

wtf am I doing here 😐

1+2+3+4+5+6+... does not converge
First we look at something else: 1+1+1+1+1+1+...
We’ll say it’s B
And 1+2+3+4+5+6+... is A
A property of B is that B=B+1
And A-B=A
The above statement has to say that B=0, because A is a real number (converges)
If B=0, this contradicts the B=B+1 statement, because 0 isn’t 0+1
We have disproved that it converges, QED

If you take the line to the corner of the diagram and mark the corner as being where it equals 0 at the termination of infinity (which, of course doesn't exist), If you move back down the line from the corner, that point on the line ceases to be zero. This proves that at no point does the line ever reach zero until it reaches infinity, which it never will.

If you then express the top border and the side border as equations joining at infinity, and introduce the point along the line as a variable within the diagram, you can summarize any point along the line up to infinity and prove that no point along the line ever reaches zero.

1859, George Bernard Riemann Hypothesized, that all the non-trivial zeros would line up on the 1/2 line, located within the critical strip, between 0 & 1. Coming here two years after you made the video (which I love),  one comment you made provokes a question. You noted how the Zeta function, of the kind shown, maps the argand grid into orthogonal geodesics "in the plane". So why, in the pursuit of a proof of Riemann,  do so many folks want to jump into the higher space of quaternions? Is it because the plane is so well arithmetized that the Riemann 'hypothesis' is just a Godel sentence that while true cannot be proven within that space and logic? If so, where does anyone get the assuring sense that adding arithmetical dimensions in a continuation of consistency will push the Godel sentence into the status of a non-Godel sentence in that domain? The constraints of analytic continuation may be the very thing that always ensures the sort of consistency that keeps the Godel sentence unprovable whether in an S symmetry or E8 . Maybe someone needs to think outside the box of analytic continuation and think of the 'anomalous' roots (prime numbers) as key elements of a buried probability theory. To me a clue in that direction might be that the most efficient primality tests seem to compete as probability estimates (which I guess is where theory of distributions may get you). The observed fact that the number of primes  up to n approaches n/ln(n)  is rather suggestive of the related roots of entropy and information theory (again, probability theory for coding). Additive for all:
The 2 functions g and h, defined by g (x) = 1 / √ (Ix-1I) and h (x) = 1 / √ (IxI 1) are two extensions of the function f defined by f (x) = 1 / √ (x-1). We have Df =] 1; + ∞ [; Dg = IR {1} and Dh =] -∞; -1 [U] 1; + ∞ [.

These 3 functions coincide on Df, but in -1 for example
g (-1) = 1 / √ (2), while f and h are not defined.

Similarly in 0: g (0) = 1, while f and h are not defined.

So, could we write h (0) = f (0) = 1, ie 1 / √ (-1) = 1 / i = - i = 1?
One would have i = - 1: another absurdity of the same kind as the two pseudo-equalities of Srinivasa Ramanujan, dating from 1910!

With g (-1) = f (-1) = 1 / √ (2), we would find the same stupidity, since we would have:
1 / √ (2) = 1 / √ (-2), so 1 = -i !!

The extension of a function f is not equal to this function, except on Df; hold it well!
The clever little trick of extending a function f on a larger set, and coming back next
"enlarge" as if by magic the domain of definition of f, is thus unveiled.

《中國人的靈魂和腦子都已經被魔鬼拿捏住了》

冪運算（英語：Exponentiation），又稱指數運算，是數學運算，表達式為 b^n。其中，b 稱為底數，而 n 稱為指數，其結果為 b 自乘 n 次。

通常指數寫成上標，放在底數的右邊。當不能用上標時，例如在編程語言或電子郵件中， b^n通常寫成b^n或b**n，也可視為超運算，記為b[3]n，亦可以用高德納箭號表示法，寫成b↑n，讀作「 b 的 n 次方」。

一種繼 + - x / 算符 之後的新算符 ^,函數符號為 exp，對應的逆算符 是對數算符 log，這意味着人類思維範式一次較大的改變。

冪算符 exp 或者指數算符 ^, 意味着人類的腦子什麼樣的場景轉換呢？

什麼叫 b ^n 指 b 自乘 n 次？

這麼一問，人類的舊的思維範式就得着了超越的提升，這就必然引發人類思考一個問題：舊的乘法、除法操作究竟是什麼意義？否則冪或指數操作符豈不是與乘法除法操作符喪失了差異性？一個數自乘究竟是什麼意思？

扣問到乘法和除法操作，自然就必須回頭審視加法操作符 + ，減法操作符 - 的本質意義了，如是人類的思維範式得着全面洗禮而進入新的揚昇場景。

西方人的頭腦這個揚昇的起點，比絕大多數中國人要高約 2500年，這個已經論證和考證過了。

但是這裡考慮到人類後學的自然知識優勢和現實中國人的腦思維狀態，就從約300年前到600年前開始，這是合理的。

什麼是一個數的自乘？

是不是很相似聖東方宇宙真理全能圖的特性？是。

自乘是指一個數自己乘多次嗎？不一定。再說了，“自乘是指一個數自己乘多次”這不是廢話嗎？等於什麼也沒有定義，什麼也沒有說。

可見，冪或者指數算符 與其反算符對數算符不是一個發明，而是一種發現，是高層次空間思維對低層次空間的舊思維的反思和揚昇。

這種反思和揚昇，因着宇宙的本徵遞歸循環迭代就引發了人腦的思維範式的全面揚昇，深入揚昇，這是思維模式的全新突破。而在西方人過去3000年中大腦的這種思維模式的幾次突破中，中國人僅僅只全面參與了一次。

自乘的意義是什麼？原來是一種自旋和旋轉，乘法也是這樣，西方人早在上個紀元15世紀時已經開始進入這種思維範式的轉換，並經歷一百年左右因着教會學校的非階段式教育模式而完成了這種轉換。

簡單給出結論，+ 算符是膨脹的概念，- 算符是收縮的概念，都是靈動概念。

自旋，旋轉，膨脹，收縮。就是這樣。

所謂的“中國噴子”幾乎都是這個特點：靠牆的石磨、半吊子，思維範式沒有改變，轉不過來，無能周延的面貌展現，所以這類人永遠是苦毒臉，無法生長出幽默的靈。這幾乎與知識無關。

A General Solution to the Riemann Hypothesis


Zeta(0) = negative one half = non trivial zero.

Proof.
1. Superimpose two unit circles.
2. Designate the vertical diameters as 2i and the horizontal
diameters as 2x.
3. Starting at zero degrees and rotating counterclockwise,
the points of axes along the circumference then assume
the values (1, 0); (0, i); (-1, 0) and (0,-i).
4. Pin the common point of the two unit circles at (1; 0)
such that this point is restricted from moving.
5. Reduce the diameter of one of the unit circles by half.
This creates an inner circle of diameter i vertically and
diameter x horizontally, which is pegged/pinned to the
larger unit circle at point (1; 0):
6. This pegged inner circle is identical in every respect to
the larger parent unit circle except it has been scaled to
half the size of the larger unit circle.
7. The origin of the parent unit circle assumes various
equivalent values
Cartesian: zero, plus or minus 1
Fermatian: zero, limit, derivative, maxima, minima,
plus and minus 1, one half, i

Newtonian: zero, shrinking the 2i secant to zero= i = limit = derivative = maxima = minima:

Inner Circle shift: The (-1; 0) point of the reduced
circle now occupies the origin of the larger parent circle.

8. The origin of the reduced/inner circle is identical to the
origin of the larger parent circle. They differ only in
location.

9. Thus since i = 0 then the entirety of the i diameter of
the reduced /inner circle is, and must be, zero.
10. The same result may be obtained by shrinking the 2i
diameter/secant of the parent circle to the length of the
i = zero diameter/secant of the inner circle.
11. Thus the i diameter comprises the critical line and since
its entirety is composed of zeroes then these zeroes are,
obligatorily, non trivial zeroes.
12. Given step 7 and Figure 2.0.1, i is equivalent to the tangent = m = slope.
13. Vis a vis the parent circle, given Figure 16.3.2 this slope
is manifest as the hypotenuse (tangent line) of a right
triangle of height i and base .5x or one half x.
14. This results in the formation of a negative .5 slope or negative one half slope
or a
positive 2 precessional rate where slope = m = negative one half.
15. Therefore m = i = 0 = nontrivial zero = negative one half.
16. Therefore critical line equals

i = 0 = non trivial zero= negative one half = Zeta(0).

17. Thus is it proven that
Zeta(0) =negative one half=non trivial zero.
QED
Solved  the Riemann hypothesis.  In short  s=negative one half=0.

It would make life a lot easier if everyone could agree to use a different character from the = sign when dealing with infinite sums that do not converge. Early in this video you use the form of words "in a certain sense" to describe the association between (-1/12) and the sum 1+2+3+4...... If it were up to me I would suggest the universal adoption of the ~ sign.
Then we would write 1-1+1-1+..........~ 1/2, or 1-2+3-4+.........~(1/4), or 1+2+3+4+.......~ (-1/12).
Those who recoil from these concepts because an = sign is being used might then be able to move on to understand that this is not complete nonsense. I speak as one who struggled for a long time to come to terms with this stuff.

The main point is missed in almost all contemporary discussions of deep mathematical behaviors, including the interesting behaviors here. It relates to a not fully understood relationship between the number of visual symbols used to represent a 'counted amount' (no matter the operations or order of operations that results in the 'counted amount'), and the number of 'counting operations and types of counting' used in computing the 'counted amount'. This is a kind of meta-mathematics relationship that in simplistic terms expresses the limits of quantitative thinking as regards the symbolic representations used for quantitation.

Namely, since the 'counted amount' itself arises from the process of doing the 'counting', expressions of 'equality' or 'equivalence', which use mathematical expressions that 'concentrate' one or other of these two notions ('counted amount' or 'counting') into expressions and notation on opposite sides of the equal sign', will result in paradoxes, nonsensical sums/products and an endless array of mathematical puzzles which can make no obvious mathematical, arithmetic, or logical sense without framing them with new or additional arbitrary definitions and proposed methods.

The key to all these issues (if any is to be found), is in the meta-mathematics involved.....and more importantly, the conscious 'notions of mind' which represent the origin of the symbols and symbolic operations used as relates to the notions of 'counted amount' and 'counting'.

Skipping these difficult questions when chasing fundamental behaviors is chasing your tail.

Sorry, but you didn't need derivatives. Why would you think that 1 + 2 + 3 + ... is not -1/12? What proof do you have? You must add axioms to the finitely lengthed sum axioms - so you're obviously not dealing with something that should even be called a sum to prevent misleading. For example, a proof involving the right side being greater than 1 or 2 because there are no negatives being added to it would have to use some made up axiom for infinitely many inductive addition expressions being transitive, which has no mathematical reasoning except human bias with algebraic notation. Convergence is a statement about error and provides a definition for a misleading enumeration called 'infinite sum' in traditional math, which obviously isn't actually a sum, but a convergence statement. (hence the quotes) If you don't believe me then just look it up on wikipedia. The formal definition is listed there. Then we have this video asserting continuity and we also have Ramanujan adding simple axioms to get a finite result of -1/12. So, nature points in apparently multiple ways, but they're all just one, that it's -1/12. People are just so used to doing algebra that they ignore the ellipsis and somehow think they can just assume that it's very large, but not different. No. It's different. That's the point. Infinite means not finite. It means different. Like set apart - something else - not the same - holy - cut and separated. How do I get this through people's heads?

In case anyone got lost early on, another way to think of how the zeta function only seems to work for s>1 is surprisingly simple. Think about how we calculate the function. It's a sigma to infinity, starting at 1, summing 1/n^s. Well that means it always starts with 1/1^s. No matter what your exponent is, a base 1 will be 1 raised to any power. Therefore, the first term of this is always 1/1, which simplifies to 1. If the first term is 1, and you add anything, you will get a number greater than one, because 1/n^s cannot be negative without n being negative. And n starts at 1 so n will never be negative. Therefore, no matter what, this function must be 1+something. And this is why for the Riemann Zeta Function, it is only defined for s>1.

Divergent series are not bad. Just don't think of the sigma symbol as meaning "sum all the terms in the sequence". Heck, even for convergent series (series whose partial sums approach a limit), you should not think of "sum all the terms in the sequence"... it does not make sense arithmetically to sum an infinite number of terms especially in terms of associativity and commutativity. In this sense, convergent series are just as "evil" as divergent series. You need to come up with the "partial sums approach a limit" construct to get your answer. In fact, there possibly endless such constructs we can come up with (ex: Fourier methods) to get an answer from a convergent series and they all seem somewhat artificial to me. However, they all generally agree on the answer (when they work) which gives merit to the whole framework. I feel like there is something deeper about infinite series (convergent or divergent) that we are all missing the point of. I also feel like part of the problem is that we need a new notation and abolish the capital sigma symbol for these types of problems. Perhaps 3Blue1Brown should give a video that demystifies infinite series?

The problem in understanding an infinite divergent sum is that people intuitively think of it in terms of its finite partial sums, and what those partial sums approach as more and more terms are added. But that's the wrong approach. You can't really determine the value, or the properties of that value, of the infinite sum by examining its partial sums. At least not for divergent series.

One typical mistake that this leads to is to make assumptions like "the sum of two positive integers is a positive integer, therefore an infinite sum of positive integers must be a positive integer". But this is, of course, incorrect. You cannot make that conclusion from the partial sums.

There's a beautiful example of how making deductions about an infinite sum from its partial sums leads to incorrect conclusions: Consider the infinite sum 1 - 1/3 + 1/5 - 1/7 + 1/9 - 1/11 + ... Is the result rational?

If one were to apply the flawed logic, one would think "the sum of two rational numbers gives a rational number, therefore the sum of infinitely many rational numbers must give a rational number". But of course that's incorrect. In reality that sum gives pi/4, which is irrational. You cannot make conclusions about the result of the infinite sum based on its partial finite sums.

In the same vein, thinking that the infinite sum "1+2+3+4+5+..." must give "infinity" is incorrect thinking. Firstly, "infinity" is a nonsensical answer. It's not an actual number. Secondly, it follows the flawed logic of thinking that the properties of the finite partial sums, and what they approach, tells something about the properties of the result.

This thinking can be used with convergent series, but it cannot be used with divergent ones. "Infinity" is not really a sensible answer.

It is completely valid within the context of mathematical reason to claim that the sum of all natural integers does equal to -1/12 simply because it is sensical to say that Riemann-Zeta(-1) does equal said sum. In the video, it is mentioned that the function is defined at s=-1 not by the original sum, but by the analytical continuation. However, the analytical continuation simply extends the definition of the sum so that it is also defined at -1. Remember, the exponential function f(x) = exp(x) is only originally defined for real arguments. Notwithstanding, we know that exponentiation is now an operation defined for all complex numbers, and we know that e^πi=-1. Mathematicians do not say that the analytic continuation of the exponential function for x=πi is evaluated to be -1. Instead, they use the continuation to extend the definition of exponentiation itself and then claim that exp(x)=-1. The definition of infinite sums is not defined in principle for divergent sums. However, we can extend the definition so that infinite sums can be defined also for divergent sums, and rather than saying the evaluation of the analytic continuation of the function that expresses the sum equals a certain value, we prefer to say that the extended definition of the sum allows to say that such divergent sum simply equals such value by said extended definition. Therefore, -1/12 = the sum of all natural numbers because Riemann-Zeta(-1) = -1/12 by its extended definition. The definition itself is extended by the analytical continuation, not just the mapping of the function, in the same way that exponentiation has an extended definition rather than simply an extended mapping from continuation. Because, to say otherwise, it would mean that exponentiation at complex numbers is still not meaningful, yet we can assign numbers to the analytic continuation of exponentiation for all numbers. And that is actually very different and very painful. That would mean that the identity e^πi=-1 is false since exponentials for complex numbers are undefined. For this type of reasoning to be consistent, we either need to give that and many other identities, or we have to declare that the Riemann-Zeta Function has an extended definition which makes divergent sums meaningful within the context of finite complex numbers. The latter is simply preferable due to mathematical convenience.

Saying 1+2+3+4+5+6+7+...=-1/12 is like saying the position of an object whose initial position on a line and velocity were 0m and 0.5m/s respectively would have the position of -1/12m after ∞ seconds have passed where the object is accelerating at 1m/s^2. It's simply nonsensical and wrong. The object's actual position at ∞ seconds would be (0.5∞^2+0.5∞)m.

I'm new to analytic continuation, seeing it animated really helped me understand that all sorts of transformations really can be performed on a 2D space while preserving this highly ambiguous seeming constraint of preserving the angle between straight lines.

So not that the sum of the natural numbers is 1/12, although maybe that it can be thought of as such.

But that there is a more general sum called the "Zeta Reman Function" that is defined for a part of the complex plane.

And that a more specific version (parameter = -1) of the only analytic (complex angle preserving) continuation of this sum, is -1/12, which would equal the sum of the natural numbers if it were the original Zeta Reman, except that is is not.

I never knew this before.

Analytic continuations are indeed unique for a specific function, that much is true. What almost nobody seems to mention is that there are almost certainly other functions that coincide with 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + … for some input, where the analytic continuation of the function assigns some value to that input that is completely different from -1 / 12.

A simple example for a different divergent sum is to look at x / (1 + x) as an analytic continuation to s₁(x) = x - x² + x³ - …. This assigns s₁(1) = 1 - 1 + 1 - 1 + 1 - … = 1/2, which is consistent with some partial sums based analyses. However, looking at s₂(x) = x - x² + x⁴ - x⁵ + x⁷ - … (where the exponents are all natural numbers that are not multiples of 3), the analytic continuation is x / (x² + x + 1) which gives us s₂(1) = 1 - 1 + 1 - 1 + … = 1/3.

I didn't see the video yet but it seems like the visualisation of the function revolves around a planar representation so I can confidently say I have a diffferent representation because it's 3D.

Essentially, here's the idea :
you can represent any function of the complex variable as a surface in 3D.

To do so, I parametrize the surface in this way :
For the X-coord : Re(f(z))
For the Y-coord : Im(f(z))
For the Z-coord : Re(z)
Where, of course, z is the complex variable, but itself parametrized in rectangular coordinates, z = u + i*v, with (u,v) the two parameters that define a surface, and f is the complex function of complex variable.

It might look a bit arbitrary, but after experimenting with it a little bit you can understand how it works and feel quite easily (I did this on a free website called mathstud.io because it was the simplest way to do it, but that's just a suggestion anything will do, WolframAlpha is clearly supieror for the Zeta function because of the computing time but you can't really zoom in and move around as much as you want), a good exercise is to plot a few polynomials and understand how to spot the zeroes or graphically evaluate the function for certain values.

Even I don't know exactly how it works but it relates a lot to vector transformations and also parametric equations. If you take a set of connected line segments that make up an open polygon and connect their midpoints, including the start and end points of the first and last line segments, respectively, you get a new set of line segments that make a new open polygon.
